author: @gurufocus
title: Energy Transfer Announces Increase in Quarterly Cash Distribution | ET Stock News
text:
- Energy Transfer LP (
ET,Financial) increases its quarterly cash distribution to $0.3275 per common unit, marking a more than 3% rise from Q1 2024. - The cash distribution will be paid on May 20, 2025, to unitholders of record as of May 9, 2025.
- Energy Transfer will release Q1 2025 earnings on May 6, 2025, followed by a conference call later that day.
Energy Transfer LP (ET) has announced a significant increase in its quarterly cash distribution for the first quarter of 2025, elevating it to $0.3275 per common unit. This adjustment represents an over 3% increase compared to the first quarter of 2024, with the annualized cash distribution now reaching $1.31 per unit.
The upcoming cash distribution is scheduled for payment on May 20, 2025. Eligibility for this payment is determined by unitholders of record as of the close of business on May 9, 2025.
Energy Transfer, a leading entity in the oil and gas midstream sector, is slated to publish its first quarter earnings for 2025 on May 6, 2025, once the market concludes its trading activities. Furthermore, the company has organized a conference call on the same day at 3:30 p.m. Central Time/4:30 p.m. Eastern Time to delve into these earnings and provide the latest company updates. The call will be accessible via live internet webcast on Energy Transfer's official site, with subsequent availability for replay.
Energy Transfer's strategic portfolio, comprised of extensive energy assets totaling over 130,000 miles of pipeline infrastructure across 44 states, underscores its vast influence in the energy sector. Additionally, Energy Transfer holds significant stakes in Sunoco LP (SUN) and USA Compression Partners, LP (USAC), enhancing its diversified energy operations.
topics: Economy, Business and Finance->energy and resource

author: hindi.sportskeeda.com
title: Extreme heat plagues Brisbane International 2024: Aryna Sabalenka, Daria Kasatkina, Sloane Stephens & others highlight scorching temperatures
text:
') > -1) { addClass($('.section-container'), 'pill-tag'); } Aryna Sabalenka, Daria Kasatkina and Sloane Stephens Like what you are reading? Unlock the Full Story for Free! Sign in with Google Continue with Facebook Login using other methods Aryna Sabalenka, Daria Kasatkina, Sloane Stephens and several other tennis players have reacted to the extreme temperatures they are currently practicing in ahead of the Brisbane International, with the mercury soaring above 35 degrees Celsius (95 Fahrenheit).
Several ATP and WTA players have landed in Brisbane in the middle of the Australian summer, to commence their 2024 campaigns at the 250 and 500 events, respectively. The tournament's main draw is scheduled from December 31–January 7, whereas the qualifiers are already underway. Meanwhile, those who have earned a direct entry to the main draw have started their on-court preparations.
On Friday, December 29, the likes of Aryna Sabalenka, Daria Kasatkina and Sloane Stephens took the practice court during the day session. They shared glimpses of their training while also highlighting that they were grappling with extreme heat .
Sabalenka, the top seed at the WTA 500 Brisbane International, revealed the temperature during her practice to be 37 degrees Celsius (approximately 99 Fahrenheit). 2017 US Open champion Sloane Stephens and World No. 27 Anastasia Potapova, too, accorded with the World No. 2.
Meanwhile, for former World No. 8 Daria Kasatkina, former World No. 1 Karolina Pliskova, and 2022 French Open semifinalist Martina Trevisan, the mercury nudged 38 degrees Celsius (over 100 Fahrenheit).
Kasatkina also showed her sunburned face to her fans on social media.
Aryna Sabalenka, Daria Kasatkina and Sloane Stephens on Instagram Other tennis players on Instagram It is worth noting that the Australian Bureau of Meteorology had issued a ‘Severe Heatwave Warning’ for Brisbane on December 27, stating that the extreme conditions were expected to last through December 29.
This isn’t the first time that the tennis players have had to bear the brunt of the summer Down Under. With the entire Australian swing taking place in late December and across January, there have been numerous instances annually, where the play has been halted or the competitors have retired due to fatigue.
Just this year at the 2023 Australian Open, the Extreme Heat Policy was put in place and several matches were suspended when the temperature crossed the tournament’s Heat Stress Scale threshold of 5.0.

author: Shannon Brown
title: Met Office severe warning for 75mph winds over New Year - Devon Live
text: The Met Office has issued a severe weather warning ahead of the New Year's weekend as the country recovers from Storm Gerrit. Just days after the storm wreaked havoc on roads, damaged properties and cut power across the UK, another band of powerful winds are set to strike the nation. The warnings covers the whole of the South West, parts of western Wales and the South English coastline. The Met Office has said this wave of bad [weather](https://www.devonlive.com/all-about/weather) is caused by an active cold front which will move eastwards on Saturday, December 30 and into New Year's Eve. The alert is in place from 11am on Saturday until 3am on Sunday morning. The Exeter-based forecaster says: "A spell of strong and gusty winds will move east across England and Wales, bringing some disruption to travel and services." There may be some disruption to road, rail, ferry and air transport services, power cuts and large waves along the coastline. "An active cold front will move east across England and Wales during Saturday and into Sunday and will be characterised by strong winds and some heavy rain," the Met Office adds. "Gusts of 45-50 mph widely, but squally near the cold front with some gusts around 60 mph, whilst the strongest gusts are likely near coasts in the west and south, with 65-75 mph in places." It comes just days after similar conditions brought by Storm Gerrit. Parts of the UK faced winds of more than 80mph, with trees and scaffolding blown down by the powerful gusts. In Greater Manchester, around 100 properties were damaged by a 160mph 'tornado' which reportedly swept through the city. The warning is expected to end at around 3am on Sunday, December 31 and the strong winds are likely to weaken through the day and into January 1. Though the warning is just for wind, heavy rain is also expected the batter the region. Steven Ramsdale is a Met Office Chief Forecaster. He said: “This system is likely to bring a range of weather including hill snow. Heavy rain will spread across all but the far north on Saturday affecting similar areas previously affected by Storm Gerrit. However, this rainfall will be a step down from that seen during Storm Gerrit.” What to Expect - Some delays to road, rail, air and ferry transport are likely - It’s likely that some coastal routes, sea fronts and coastal communities will be affected by spray and/or large waves - Probably some bus and train services affected, with some journeys taking longer - Some short term loss of power and other services is possible - Delays for high-sided vehicles on exposed routes and bridges likely

author: Jordan Darensbourg
title: Austin should be seeing some beneficial rain soon
text: AUSTIN, Texas — A widespread rain will move into Central Texas for Tuesday afternoon and Tuesday evening. There could be pockets of heavy rain and embedded storms, but we are not anticipating any issues with severe weather. This is just the first round of rain for the week, and it will likely bring a widespread quarter-inch to 1 inch of beneficial rainfall. The second round of rain will move in on Friday. Models remain in strong agreement that another system will produce widespread showers and a few embedded storms, but we won't know the exact timing for another couple of days. As a result of both of these system, we're expecting most of the KVUE area to pick up a half-inch to one and a half inches of beneficial rain over the next seven days. This pattern is looking much more typical of an El Niño winter, and we hope it continues into the back half of January to improve our ongoing drought. The KVUE Weather Team will continue to monitor this developing forecast. In the meantime, the extended forecast can be found below:
